item.name: Images, Sounds, Cultures I
item.description: This course aims to familiarize students with the basic issues of the image, the visual world, representation and culture at a number of levels. What is seeing, what is hearing and what are the cultural determinants that are at work in the processes of audio-visual perception? Special emphasis will be placed on spectatorship and the place of the 'spectacle' will be discussed extensively. The significance of photography and moving images within the framework of art and technology will also be examined. There will be a special module devoted to 'America', in order to study how these issues materialize in the context of a country as an icon. These topics will be covered, by drawing upon a wide range of cases. Students are expected to participate in discussions, bringing their own experiences and personal work that they have produced.

week.description:
Image, Art & Technology I / Brief History of Western Art

A brief historical review of Western Art with references to specific 'masterpieces' that represent their era. The objective of this week is to show the students the evolution of Western Art in terms of content, techniques, authorship, movements, venues, art market, social changes, audience etc.

References / resources:

Zaczek, Iain. Masterworks. Ed. Rachel Bean. Kent, UK: Grange Books, 2003.

Berger, John. Ways of Seeing. 1972; 1973. Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1977.

Image, Art & Technology II / Brief History of Photography

A brief historical review of photography from its invention to day with references to specific photographers and their work. The objective of this week is to show to the students the ever changing and multi-functional nature of photography, its relation to and interaction with social dynamics and other art disciplines, particularly painting and the moving images. Special emphasis will be placed on repeating themes and attitudes over time, and the changing perception of photography as a result of common daily use and introduction of new technologies.

References / resources:

A brief review of photography today and its role as a medium in contemporary art. Special emphasis will be placed on the digital revolution and its effects on the representation of reality in photography.

item.name: Photography Techniques
item.description: In this very much production oriented course, the students are expected to acquire the basic technical skills involved in photography such as exposure techniques, camera setup, framing, depth of field control, lens selection, raw image conversion, printing etc. The students are introduced to camera types, photographic equipment and accessories, materials, processes and philosophy. The course is based heavily on digital photography with only a brief introduction to the traditional analogue workflow. Special emphasis is placed on projects involving the development of camera vision and ideas. Specific concepts will be demonstrated through examples by masters of photography both from the past and today.

item.description: The second part of the course aims at developing skills regarding advanced techniques, with the compositional / conceptual aspect of the medium always emphasized. This course introduces further creative shooting and post-processing options such as panorama stitching, HDR etc. as well as darkroom experience depending on student interest and requirements of personal projects which will be completed at the end of the semester. color materials, including color negatives / slides, applied color and experimental color processes. Skills learned in the first semester are enhanced and reinforced. The class is designed to explore the inherent qualities of both analogue and digital photographic processes, so that students learn to make informed decisions in their choice of process. The course will also examine the way available technologies alter our thoughts about photography and what opportunities they provide for the picture maker. Photographic image alteration will be carried out primarily with Adobe's Photoshop software. We will explore available output methods to enable the viewing of computer pictures, as these most recent manifestations determine our mark-making urge. The course will be organized around a series of assigned mini-projects as well as an individual term project submitted as a hard-copy portfolio.

This course will engage students to make meaningful generalizations for interpreting or evaluating digital experiences and practices in digital media, art, communication and design.

item.name: Introduction to Multimedia
item.description: Multimedia delivers information through the most accessible and appropriate use of all available communication levels, i.e. text, picture, video, animation, audio and intellectual methods of interactivity. Multimedia production is where all the different digital media meet: Combining different types of media in one project requires a wide range of knowledge of each. The speed of the development of information technology and the short time between development and marketing prevents establishing standards or causes any standard to have a very short life cycle. For the same reason, the knowledge that a multimedia author can rely on becomes out of date in a very short time. This is a major problem of the authoring environment, but not the only one. Another problem with the rapid change in this market is the variety of the target machines that the end product will run on. All these make pausing the learning process impossible. But learning is always easier when one keeps track of current developments. As a process, multimedia production has its own rules and methods. This course's objective is to teach the process of MM production with hands-on experience, to discuss the basics of most media and the details of combining them in the authoring environment. In addition, the idea is to bring the participants to a level of knowledge from which they can continue following new developments.

Description

The aim of this course is to set in motion the graduation projects of the BA candidates of the VCD, FTV and POV departments and guide the students through the stages of project development and pre-production.

Finally the students will present the draft version or script of their project and a preliminary production timetable to the committee. In successfully completing the course, the students will have acquired the experience of coordinating independent projects based on investigation and research.

A student who has chosen a part-time instructor as advisor will be responsible for the consulting mode under survey of his or her supervisor.

Each student has to meet at least twice with his/her advisor and send a report to the supervisor.

item.description:
This course will be a survey of concepts, tools and methods that can be used to define and develop an MFA project in Visual Communication Design. The course is planned to familiarise the students with contemporary approaches and research methodologies in visual culture research and equip students with the necessary tools to determine appropriate methods for specific design research needs and the ability to carry out an independent research project.

The course aims to help students in developing MFA proposals step by step individually and also encouraging them to develop it in accordance with their colleagues. Students will be encouraged to develop a knowledge community by sharing the methods and daily experiences they go through during their MFA work. Individual student projects will be demonstrated at different stages during the term to allow peer students to observe the research processes of different equivalent design or art projects. Participation of other faculty members and professionals is also expected to enrich the discussions in general and for each student's specific research and development process.

Individual office hours will be organised to assist students for selecting the most appropriate research methodology for their MFA project. The required readings will be made available for the students. If necessary, additional required readings may be assigned. Further assignments and tasks may also be assigned after going through the project proposals.

item.description:
In general, the course will seek to define a series of ways of understanding and thinking that will enable an informed participation in the possibilities offered by current technologies and thinking about them. We will be assessing these in relation to the alterations they are bringing about across traditional fields of activity, knowledge and expertise.

We will thus be considering a range of practices, from different traditions in art and design, to recent innovations in those fields, to activities in the wider culture. item.name: Issues in Digital Media and Culture
item.description: This course aims to familiarise students with major theories of digital culture and media. It also introduces diverse social, artistic, theoretical and cultural practices which constitute today's digital domains and virtual environments. A major part of the course will be devoted to critically analyze the development of digital technologies from a set of activist and artistic practices and ideologies such as feminism, cross-culturalism, net activism, interface design, and media philosophy. The (re) construction of human identity and the body will be explored through a vibrant network of ideas and actions by studying cyborg theory, cyberfeminism, webcams, chatrooms, Internet mailing lists and new media art. The course will enable students to explore and respond to theories and digital productions and investigate basic ethical issues such as surveillance-privacy, censorship, gender and ethnicity, and the commercialization of the public sphere. Students are also asked to actively explore the Internet by closely investigating and participating in emerging web communities, or by making a miniature design for a digital educational and social environment.

item.name: Introduction to Art Direction
item.description:
A screenplay selected by the instructor will be read. Different readings will be done through text analysis, scene by scene breakdown of the film and color dramaturgy. Art Direction will be covered as a 'structure building process'.

Text analysis will cover the area from discovering subtext of the screenplay to dramaturgy and character analysis.

Scene by scene breakdown will be analyzed from the aspects of screenplay, actors, locations, accessories, set and costume design. The technique of 'splitting the text into as many pieces as possible and reaching a new whole by bringing them together again' will be worked on.

'Colors' will be approached from the perspective of 'the meaning produced by the visual material when two actors come together'. 'Color dramatugy' will also be studied.

The relationship with costumes and props will be discussed within the act of rearranging the location, stressing the fact that rearranging is not filling the gaps with props.

Directors invited by the instructor will discuss the art director-director relationship / working style and they will show examples on the movies.

item.name: Film and İstanbul
item.description:
This course studies 'cinematic İstanbul' as a source of inspiration for new forms of representation in space and/or time based media. The course is designed as a transdisciplinary urban practice which combines screenings, readings, lectures, field work and production. Production includes all forms of representation such as film, design and performance.

The premise of the course is that the metropolis and the cinema have created and recreated each other since the city films of the 1920s. The city of İstanbul will be studied through its filmic representations within this framework. İstanbul was a cinematic city right from the beginning of the practice of film in both senses of the term: Film production was centered in İstanbul (located in the Army Film Archives during early 20th Century and transferred to Yeşilçam during the second half of the century) and İstanbul featured in majority of the films. Therefore issues pertaining to modernization such as migration, urbanization and flÃ¢nerie (with emphasis on women in public İstanbul) can be traced in these films where İstanbul either appears in the background or is cast as a character. Filmic representation also provides a useful context for a comparative analysis. Other well-known cinematic cities or less famous ones will be used as cross-references for İstanbul in highlighting the spatial and visual connotations of modernization.

Students are required to attend all classes and screenings having read the relevant material so that they can fully participate in discussions. Each student is required to complete an individual project as the midterm assignment and to participate in a group project as the final assignment. Group projects may range from video clips to urban typography, from design of urban space to performance in that space. Interdisciplinary groups will be encouraged and field work will be required.
